poem:
**Cartoon Showdown**

In the town of paper cut-outs,  
scripted satire sharp as a blade,  
where deadlines barrel from behind  
like runaway trains,  
the ink-stained knights  
pivot on pencils,  
ready to joust—  
lawsuits like confetti  
in the closing credits,  
fearless in their cardboard kingdom,  
cells in constant motion,  
laughing in frame-by-frame defiance.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "‘Go ahead and sue me, I’m not afraid any more’: South Park’s festive special isn’t afraid of a fight Coming off its most controversial and highest rated season in years, South Park had high expectations to meet with its season finale. Given how infamously down-to-the-wire its production schedule is – showrunners Matt Stone and Trey Parker often don’t start writing scripts until the week they’re set to air, working up to the 11th hour to". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
